awd_titl_txt: GEM:  A Statistical Study of the Substorm Sequence and Phenomena Associated with Expansion Onset
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is focused on understanding the nature of substorms, a critical problem in geospace science that so far has hindered efforts to develop a predictive capability for space weather disturbances.  In the auroral ionosphere, a substorm is identified as a sudden brightening and poleward expansion of the aurora.  It is the observational manifestation of an explosive energy release high above the Earth in the stretched tail of the magnetosphere that ultimately shunts strong currents through the high-latitude ionosphere and produces precipitation of high-energy charged particles.  These inputs alter the chemistry and electrical conductivity there and heat the coupled ionosphere-upper atmosphere.  Substorm disturbances produce a variety of environmental effects that can increase satellite drag, disrupt communications and navigation systems and induce currents in the solid Earth that are capable of damaging electric power grids. 

A standard technique that the PI has used in the past is to perform a statistical analysis of the key indicators of substorms and their sequencing in time and space and compare this against various theories about substorm dynamics.  The recent development of a new substorm theory provides the motivation to incorporate both new and updated data sets into an expanded statistical study that uses newly-developed pattern recognition techniques to remove bias in the identification of observational signatures, and sophisticated correlation tools (for example, Statistics of Point Processes) to establish relative timing of physical processes as a function of substorm phases.  This study will make comprehensive lists available of time-tagged substorm signatures (i.e., auroral zone negative bay, midlatitude positive bay, Pi2 pulsations, geosynchronous magnetic field dipolarization, auroral kilometric radiation, magnetotail flows, etc.) and add to these the set of signatures implied by the new substorm theory (i.e., bursty bulk flows in the magnetotail, poleward boundary intensifications and auroral streamers in the auroral region, etc.).  The relative timing of features in the lists of observational signatures will be used to evaluate the evidence in support of the new and previous substorm theories.

por.por_cntn:
Auroral displays are the effect of the interaction of the solar wind with the Earth's magnetic field. This plasma stream from the Sun and its magnetic field couples to the Earth's field through magnetic reconnection. Recoinnectiio occurs when this interplanetary magnetic field southward antiparallel to the Earth's field on the dayside. When the coupling is strong, the Earth experiences a sequence of processes called a magnetospheric substorm. Each substorm is about three hours long with a growth, expansion, and recovery phase.
We designed this project to determine when substorm occurs, and the aurora suddenly brightens near midnight, expanding azimuthally and towards the poles. This determination used a proxy for the onset of auroral brightening called a negative bay. This proxy is a decrease in the southward component of the surface magnetic field in the auroral zone. The auroral lower (AL) index provides a measure of this variation. The signature of a bay is a minimum in AL, preceded by a rapid decrease, started by a sudden change in the slope of the AL index series. Our project created three lists of onsets with progressively smaller events. Our best list has over 200,000 onsets in the 56-year interval beginning in 1966.
Statistical analysis of these lists and the properties of the accompanying negative bays allows a quantitative description of the size, duration, and times of occurrence of auroral disturbances. The distribution of times between substorms has two peaks at 54 and 240 minutes. Size and duration have power law distributions, with most substorms having small sizes and short durations. Substorm occurrence rates and sizes are the largest in the declining phase of the solar cycle near the equinoxes. We found the typical behavior of coupling, AL, and its derivatives by stacking and averaging data segments relative to negative bay onsets. This procedure demonstrated that two other magnetic indices, the polar cap (PC) index, and the midlatitude positive bay (MPB) index, exhibit sharp slope changes simultaneously with the negative bay and auroral onsets. These effects are all consequences of an electrical current system called the substorm current wedge. Current is diverted from the tail into the dawn ionosphere, flows westward across the disturbed region near midnight, and back outward in the pre-midnight sector.
We used our list of substorms to find an interesting event and created a computer model showing the behavior of the Earth's magnetic tail during substorms. In the first step, we used ground observations to determine the time sequence of events in the aurora, magnetic pulsations, and magnetic field. We repeated this using satellite observations of plasma flow and magnetic field in the Earth's magnetic tail. In the second step, we studied the behavior of these variables in the simulation. The conclusion derived from this analysis is that the substorm begins about one hour before the auroral brightening with the start of dayside reconnection. Reconnection begins an hour later in the tail. The reconnection produces a plasma jet flowing earthward, carrying reconnected magnetic field energized particles. This plasma bubble and its magnetic field are added to the nightside magnetic field near midnight, 6-12 Earth radii behind the Earth. This addition changes the field,  reducing the tail current inside the bubble and diverting the tail current to the ionosphere in the current wedge. Particles are lost from the bubble, causing aurora.
In the stacking procedure used to obtain typical behavior, we discovered that the slope of the solar wind coupling function has a strong spike beginning about 20 minutes before onset. A positive spike occurs about 60% of the time, and a negative spike occurs about 16%. The conclusion is that a sudden increase or decrease in coupling can trigger a substorm onset. Positive pulses lead to larger substorms, while negative pulses lead to smaller ones.
Substorm lists are essential to research in different fields of magnetospheric research. Almost all forms of disturbance in the Earth's field are associated with substorms. Lists with accurate onset times and known properties of the associated activity are used to organize research projects that improve our understanding of the magnetospheric system. Radio communications, electrical utilities, underground pipelines, and global navigation are some of the systems affected by magnetic activity.
Understanding the aurora is also of interest to the general public. A travel agency specializing in trips to observe the aurora contacted us recently. We provided advice on when and where to go in the form of a simple statement they could use in advertising. Our advice was Flin Flon, Manitoba, in September, during the declining phase of the sunspot cycle. Flin Flon is the farthest south in the northern hemisphere, where the aurora routinely occurs, and the equinox is when the aurora is most probable and the strongest.
